awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Quadratically Nonlinear Micro-Resonators: Enabling Next Generation Photonic Devices and Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Description:
This project is inspired by how the immeasurable impact of electronics in our modern life is rooted in the development of a nonlinear device in a scalable and integrated form, i.e. the silicon-based transistor. Introducing resonators with strong quadratic nonlinearities to photonic devices can enable development of disruptive technologies for numerous applications. This is evident from more than 50 years of table-top nonlinear optics, over which a wide range of optical systems with extraordinary performance has been demonstrated and used for applications ranging from sensing to computing. This project is focused on bringing the depth and breadth of such functionalities to the micro-chip-scale integrated photonics, and enabling scalable solutions for a variety of real-life applications. The specific experiments of the project can lead to unprecedented solutions for our most daunting molecular sensing challenges through development of ideal compact sources for spectroscopy. They can also enable a scalable path for unconventional computing for some of our hardest computational problems in a variety of disciplines. The developed knowledge through this project will be applicable to other applications ranging from metrology to quantum information processing and optical communications. Students working on the project will get educated on conducting multi-disciplinary research, and the PI will incorporate the materials developed through this project in a course on frontiers of nonlinear optics. The team will participate in outreach activities targeting k-12 students with a large population of underrepresented minorities.

Technical DEscription:
Optical resonators with strong quadratic nonlinearities are proven to provide a broad range of functionalities that are essential for sensing and information processing applications. However, despite their outstanding performance in table-top systems, their footprint, power consumption, and cost have been prohibitive for many real-life applications. Recent development of nanoscale photonic platforms with quadratic nonlinearities, for instance in lithium niobate, has enabled access to an unexplored regime of nonlinear photonics which promises overcoming these challenges. This regime is associated with significantly large nonlinearities, low losses, and potential for dispersion engineering. This project leverages these features to introduce a disruptive line of theoretical and experimental research on quadratically-nonlinear microresonators, and aims to (i) advance our understanding of this new regime of nonlinear photonics, (ii) utilize this micro-chip-based platform to lay the foundation for development of a new class of functionalities in photonic devices and systems, and (iii) demonstrate proof-of-concept experiments for on-chip nonlinear optical systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project has resulted in more than 30 journal papers, some of which are currently under review. These publications include 2 papers in Science, 2 in Nature Photonics, 3 in Nature Physics, and 4 in Nature Communications among others. Moreover, the project has led to  more than 30 conference presentations mostly presented by the students and postdocs contributing to the project, more than 30 invited talks at Conferences and Colloquia, 3 patent applications (including 1 granted US patents), and a venture-capital-backed Caltech startup.

Some highlights of the results from the project include:

  • We have demonstrated the largest reported on-chip gain-bandwidth through optical parametric amplification (larger than 100 dB/cm over 600 nm of bandwidth) [Optica 9 (3), 303-308 (2022)]. This was enabled by combining dispersion engineering and quasi-phase matching (QPM), which is not easily available in other platforms. 
  • By advancing QPM engineering and including more complex poling structures, we have demonstrated a novel integrated device for energy-efficient (femtojoule), ultrafast (femtosecond), all-optical switching in nanophotonics with an order-of-magnitude lower switching energy-time product compared to the state of the art [Nature Photonics 16, 625–631 (2022)].
  • We developed a small-scale ultrafast nanophotonic circuit and demonstrated the generation and all-optical measurement of squeezed states on the same chip [Science 377, 1333–1337 (2022)]. The generated squeezed states span more than 25 terahertz of bandwidth supporting just a few optical cycles. The measured 4.9 dB of squeezing substantially outperforms the previous nanophotonic demonstrations and surpasses the requirements for a wide range of quantum information systems, highlighting a practical path toward scalable ultrafast quantum nanophotonics.
  • We have developed an electrically pumped actively mode-locked laser (MLL) in nanophotonic lithium niobate based on its hybrid integration with a III-V semiconductor optical amplifier [Science 382, 708-713 (2023), appeared on the cover of Science magazine]. Our MLL not only addresses the challenges associated with the size and power demand of current MLLs, but also it enables transforming the ultrafast photonic systems into nanophotonic chips, and ultimately unlocking their potential for a plethora of applications. Apart from the superior performance metrics of our demonstration compared to other nanophotonic sources, the repetition rate and the carrier-envelope-offset of the resulting frequency comb of our MLL can be flexibly controlled in a wide range using the RF driving frequency and the pump current, providing a route for fully stabilized on-chip frequency combs. 
  • We have shown that the combination of dispersion engineering and large quadratic nonlinearity can enable formation of quadratic cavity solitons, which offer practical and performance benefits over the Kerr counterparts. We have recently discovered a new flavor of such quadratic solitons and experimentally demonstrated its formation in the low-energy (picojoule) regime with a 40-fold pulse compression [Nature Photonics 16, 162–168 (2022)]. We have also demonstrated that quadratic solitons can lead to mid-infrared few-cycle frequency combs around 4 μm with a high average power and efficiency [Laser Photonics Review 2200453 (2022)]. Moreover, we have shown that formation of quadratic cavity solitons, offers an enhancement mechanism for molecular sensing, which is not limited by the typical constraints of linear sensing schemes [arXiv:2301.07826]. 
  • We have shown that with a properly dispersion-engineered and spectrally tailored cavity design, one can achieve ultra-widely tunable optical parametric oscillators (OPOs) in nanophotonics. In the quasi-continuous-wave regime, we generate output wavelengths tunable from 1.53 μm to 3.25 μm in a single chip, representing the widest tuning range for a nanophotonic source in the infrared [Science Advances 9, eadf9711 (2023)]. In the frequency comb regime, using a similar OPO principle, we have demonstrated frequency combs tunable from visible to mid-infrared on a single chip [Nature Communications 14 (1), 6549 (2023)], introducing new opportunities for integrated frequency comb sources.
  • We have also broken the energy and size barriers of ultrabroad frequency comb generation and demonstrated multi-octave frequency comb generation using an OPO with only femtojoules of pump energy [arXiv:2309.04545]. We discovered that an OPO can undergo a temporal self-cleaning mechanism by transitioning from an incoherent operation regime, which is typical for operation far above threshold, to an ultrabroad coherent regime, corresponding to the nonlinear phase compensating the OPO cavity detuning. Such a temporal self-cleaning mechanism and the subsequent multi-octave coherent spectrum has not been explored in previous OPO designs and features a relaxed requirement for the quality factor and relatively narrow spectral coverage of the cavity. We achieve orders of magnitude reduction in the energy requirement compared to the other spectral broadening techniques and highlight a path towards energy-efficient ultra-short-pulse nanophotonic sources.

Moreover, the project has been essential in educating several students in the PI's lab including 5 graduated PhD students, and several undergraduate students, many of whom are considered under-represented minorities. The PI has leveraged the material developed through this project for introducing and teaching three new courses at Caltech.
